title: Will the UN Security Council adopt a resolution concerning Myanmar by 31 December 2017?
preds: Not bold enough of a body - reports and investigations from countries who are not council members (Canada etc) will be the excuse to delay
Last call for bets, this weekend is.
Likely but not likely that quickly.
security council  is  too obsessed with Israel  to  actually  care about  other  regions  of  the  world.
They have not done it yet.
No time left. Very unlikely an agreement could be made.

It is almost Dec. 31 and there is only 1 working day left for the resolution. It's very unlikely that the security council will consider the issue important enough to act tomorrow or over the weekend.
not enough time left in the challenge

Four days left. No statements or reports from the UN Security Council. Largest block of support for a resolution would come from OIC who are better represented in the General Assembly than in the Security Council.
Unless a major massacre occurs before date
They should but they should have already... also they're maybe not meeting but because of the holiday.
Not before Kono visits in January.
Unlikely in Christmas/ New Year period.

U.N. denies arrested Reuters reporters in Myanmar had given it information Nichols, Richardson and Aung (2017) YANGON (Reuters) - Two Reuters reporters arrested in Myanmar had not passed any information to the United Nations, the world body said, rejecting a report published in domestic media which suggested that could be the reason for their detention. A report published online by the Irrawaddy magazine on Tuesday had cited an unnamed source “who has close ties with military intelligence” as saying that the two men had passed photographs obtained during their reporting on violence in the western state of Rakhine to the U.N. Asked about the report, U.N. spokesman Stephane Dujarric said on Wednesday: “We can confirm that Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo do not work for the United Nations and have not contacted the United Nations regarding the situation in Rakhine State.” Reuters also denied that Wa Lone, 31, and Kyaw Soe Oo, 27, who have been in detention since Dec. 12, had worked with the U.N. or any other organization (para. 1-4). Nichols, M., Richardson, A. & Aung, T., T. (2017). U.N. denies arrested Reuters reporters in Myanmar had given it information. Reuters. World. Myanmar. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-journalists-un/u-n-denies-arrested-reuters-reporters-in-myanmar-had-given-it-information-idUSKBN1EF1K2
Won’t get past a veto by China.

UNITED NATIONS (Reuters) - The United Nations Security Council urged the Myanmar government on Monday to “ensure no further excessive use of military force in Rakhine state,” where violence has forced more than 600,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee the Buddhist-majority Asian country.
To appease council veto powers Russia and China, Britain and France dropped a push for the Security Council to adopt a resolution on the situation and the 15-member body instead unanimously agreed on a formal statement.

COMMENT:  Unlikely
Bad timing + short window + the US, UK, and FR are unlikely to move this fast.
The increasing malnutrition of children being reported in the Rohyngian refugee camps will precipitate a resolution by the security council.

China is a permanent member and not seeking to vote for a resolution against Myanmar since it believes other channels must be used in order Myanmar brings back stability.

Agree China and Russia block. Resolution from other UN Committees likely.

Chinese support the Myanmar government, making passing security council resolutions difficult. However, statements coming from the UN commissioner for human rights pushing for action and countries including the UK and France wanting a resolution do increase the likelihood.  
Overall opposition from China and Russia mean resolutions being made quickly are unlikely.

SC Meeting on Dec 12th. There might be a general resolution condemning violence but it looks more likely a General Assembly vote to just send an envoy to investigate. China and Russia do not appear to be in favor of SC action. https://www.un.org/press/en/2017/sc13117.doc.htm
Well, they haven't so far. UNable, UNlikely, UNworkable.

Lots of diplomatic jawboning. The Security Council  presidente issued a milquetoast statement condeming Myanmar behavior early November over strong objections of powerful Security Council member China. But condemnations do not a resolution make, especially when the folks in Beijing speak loudly and carry a big bamboo stick.
The weight of the personality of Aung San Su Kyi appears to still be buying time for Myanmar. Barring any deterioration in the situation, 2017 should close quietly.
Topical. Want to be seen to be doing something before years end. Low hanging fruit

China doesn't want a resolution on Myanmar. But since China rejected the previous draft resolution, perhaps the next one will not be as strongly worded. I think there is an above-zero chance that China could be persuaded to accept a resolution this month. Note the fine print in the question: it doesn't have to be a resolution condemning hostilities in Myanmar.

With China not on board, and the refugee problem not being on the scale of the Syrian one and the fact its not producing pictures of dead babies in water while crossing into Europe, the impact and the pressure is not there to really push it hard.
Just at the moment, I doubt that the Security Council could adopt a resolution congratulating its grandmother on her 100th birthday.

UNSC briefing and consultation regarding Myanmar situation currently scheduled for 12 DEC. Probably not enough consensus before end of year to adopt policy, along with all the end-of-year reporting and review.

Briefings and consultations will occur during Dece,bed, but there is currently no resolution offered.  I suspect that it might come shortly after that.   How the votes in the security counc8l will be distributed (including a veto) drives ate f the IFP.  To be updated as new knowledge becomes available.
Short time frame and only if China changes its veto position (assumed rare occurrence)
China would veto any such resolution.
China will veto any attempt to pass resolution on the issue.
recent agreement with Bangladesh to return refugees.
China vetoed resolution on November 7. New one not likely.

The U.N. Security Council 'Strongly Condemns' Crackdown on Rohingya Muslims Lederer (2017) November 7, states that: UNITED NATIONS) — The U.N. Security Council unanimously approved a statement Monday strongly condemning the violence that has caused more than 600,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee from Myanmar to Bangladesh, a significant step that still fell short of a stronger resolution that Western nations wanted but China opposed. The presidential statement calls on Myanmar’s government “to ensure no further excessive use of military force in Rakhine State” and take immediate steps to respect human rights. It expresses “grave concern” at reports of human rights violations in Rakhine by Myanmar’s security forces against the Rohingya. These include “the systematic use of force and intimidation, killing of men, women and children, sexual violence and … the destruction and burning of homes and property,” it says. Britain initially circulated a Security Council resolution with similar language, backed by the U.S., France and other council members. But resolutions are legally binding and diplomats said China, a neighbor and ally of Myanmar, was strongly opposed. China is one of the five countries that have veto power on the council. So, Britain and France turned the resolution into a presidential statement, which becomes part of the council’s record but does not have the legal clout of a resolution (para. 1-5). Lederer, E., M. (2017). he U.N. Security Council 'Strongly Condemns' Crackdown on Rohingya Muslims. Associated Press. World. Myanmar. Retrieved from  
http://time.com/5012779/security-council-myanmar-rohingya/
